title: 106_hr583
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" and addresses the treatment of Assistant United States Attorneys. The Act "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" amends the Civil Service Retirement System and Federal Employees' Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys in the definition of a law enforcement officer. The Act "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" includes Assistant United States Attorneys in the definition of a law enforcement officer under the Federal Employees' Retirement System. The Act "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" amends definitions and effective dates related to Assistant United States Attorneys. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. 
For purposes of this section, an incumbent is an individual appointed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the effective date of this Act. The Department of Justice must provide notice to these individuals regarding their election rights under this Act within 6 months of its effective date. Incumbents have the option to elect to be treated according to the amendments made by this Act or as if the Act had never been enacted. Failure to make a timely election will have consequences. Failure to make a timely election under this subsection shall be treated in the same way as an election made on the last day allowable. An election must be made before the 90th day after the notice is provided or the incumbent separates from service. No change in retirement coverage shall occur before the enactment of this Act for any incumbent. Interim status provision ensures no change in retirement coverage for incumbents until an election is made under the Act. Retroactive effect applies to service performed by Assistant United States Attorneys before and after the election date. The Act ensures no change in retirement coverage for incumbents until an election is made. Makeup contributions are required to be remitted to the Office of Personnel Management by the Department of Justice. The Act requires makeup contributions to be remitted to the Office of Personnel Management for all incumbents before the effective date of their election, with the amount deposited in the Treasury of the United States to the credit of the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The Act mandates makeup contributions for all incumbents before their election's effective date, with the amount deposited in the Treasury to the credit of the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations, including determining interest on the contributions. The term "Assistant United States Attorney" is defined as an assistant appointed under section 542 of title 28, United States Code.
